html_content:
How to Deal

More in How to Deal ›

  2. The Benefits of Moderate Exercise

    High-intensity workouts get a lot of attention and can be great for health. But moderate physical activity may have metabolic advantages.

    2h agoBy Gretchen Reynolds

  4. How Nothingness Became Everything We Wanted

    Even before the pandemic, American culture was embracing numbness as an antidote for the overload of digital capitalism. But is it a real escape — or another trap?

    2d agoBy Kyle Chayka

What to Eat

More in What to Eat ›

  2. What to Cook Right Now

    Red curry lentils, a shrimp scampi with orzo or a satisfying chicken French.

    3d agoBy Sam Sifton

  3. What to Cook This Week

    Jamaican oxtail stew, white borscht, spicy noodles with chicken and peanuts: Transport yourself by way of your kitchen.

    January 18, 2021By Sam Sifton

  4. I Recommend Eating Chips

    When our horizons are narrow, junk food — shelf-stable, reliably flavored and yet endlessly unique — offers us a taste of infinity.

    January 13, 2021By Sam Anderson

  5. Unlocking the Secrets of Your Pantry

    So much of 2020 was about starting from staples, but Yotam Ottolenghi hopes we can keep those cooking lessons in the new year.

    2d agoBy Yotam Ottolenghi

What to Watch

More in What to Watch ›

  4. The Best Movies on Amazon Prime Video Right Now

    New films, and classics, just keep coming, but you don’t have to drill down to find the finest selections to stream. We’ll do the heavy lifting. You press play.

    January 14, 2021By Jason Bailey

Pass the Time

More in Pass the Time ›

  4. The Daily’s Audio Guide to the Inauguration

    For Joe Biden, and for our country, it’s been a long road to this day. Here’s what you need to know about the political history and policy plans of America’s president-elect.

    20h agoBy Lauren Jackson

found_urls.title: John Lurie Doesn’t Paint Happy TreesHis new series for HBO, “Painting With John,” is a meditative and often joyful blend of painting and personal storytelling. But Bob Ross it isn’t.Jan. 20, 2021Erik Tanner for The New York Times

The Mystery of the Painting Thieves LoveWhat is it about a Frans Hals painting housed at a tiny Dutch museum that has made it so popular with thieves, who have stolen it three times since 1988?Jan. 18, 2021Xiao Hua Yang

What It Means to Look at Paintings of SnowToday, works depicting the blankets of white that were once synonymous with the season evoke longing for a winter that never comes.Jan. 19, 2021Rights courtesy of Plattsburgh State Art Museum, State University of New York, USA, Rockwell Kent Collection, Bequest of Sally Kent Gorton. All rights reserved. Photo: © Whitney Museum of Art/Licensed by Scala, via Art Resource, NY

Improve Your Life With These Tiny ChoresCompleting these five home projects — like undergoing a good spring cleaning — will give you and your home a fresh start in the new year.Jan. 16, 2021Jordan Awan
How to Update Your Work-From-Home RoutineHere are a few ways to make working from home — during a pandemic, to boot — slightly better.Michael Hession
Arrange Your Clutter Into CollectionsYou’re at home all the time — why not improve how you display your favorite things?Lisa Congdon

Finding a Foothold for Nordic Skiing in Rural AlaskaThe harsh wind-hammered tundra sometimes complicates the prospect, as do the polar bears. But the children are enthusiastic pupils.Jan. 18, 2021Seth Adams
Critic’s NotebookPlaying Bach, Was He a Pioneer or a Reactionary?The conductor and keyboardist Karl Richter’s legacy can be explored anew with a 100-disc box set.By David Allen
Masks Aren’t Going Away, So Consider the Mask ChainA practical accessory also adds a bit of flair to your pandemic look. Just ask A.O.C. or J.Lo.By Valeriya Safronova

Ask WellWhat You Can Do to Avoid the New Coronavirus Variant Right NowIt’s more contagious than the original and spreading quickly. Upgrade your mask and double down on precautions to protect yourself.By Tara Parker-Pope
Everything’s Coming Up CozyColorful snowsuits and sleeping-bag coats are selling like hot cakes during the pandemic’s difficult winter period.By Alexandra Zissu
Fashion ReviewOnesies, Long Johns and Union Suits for a WFH AgeIn Milan, men’s wear designers influenced by lockdown propose a uniform for a new work world.By Guy Trebay

Kamala Harris Has Always Worn Pearls. Now, in Sisterhood, So Will They.Women across the country are pledging to wear pearls on Inauguration Day to support the country’s first female vice president-elect.By Alyson Krueger

Why Medical Tourism Is Drawing Patients, Even in a PandemicThe coronavirus pandemic has devastated medical tourism, but pent-up demand remains for affordable treatment in foreign lands.By Ceylan Yeginsu
How Climbers Reached the Summit of K2 in Winter for the First TimeIt was a prideful journey for the Nepalese climbers, who historically haven’t received their due.By Adam Skolnick and Bhadra Sharma

The Best Shoes for Knee Arthritis May Be Stiff, Stable and Cushioned OnesPeople with knee arthritis were less likely to report pain and stiffness if they wore stable, supportive shoes, versus flat-soled, flexible ones.By Nicholas Bakalar
Tip How to Fix a Brake LightImmediately replace bulbs that are out. Get some screwdrivers. Needle-nose pliers come in handy, too.By Malia Wollan
